fields.content:
This website was built by Ecotrust on behalf of the Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network (OFSSGN) to track progress and measure success for the farm to school movement in Oregon. The mission of the OFSSGN is to convene farm to school stakeholders statewide to promote the health and well-being of youth, families, farms, and the environment by increasing access to locally grown and locally processed food in schools and by supporting food and garden-based education in Oregon.

For more information about the OFSSGN, contacting Managing Director Megan Kemple at megan at lanefood.org.

How are you using the data on this website? Do you know of any information we're missing? We'd like to hear from you!  Contact the project team.

{"image": null, "display_title": "

Farm to School Counts

", "search_description": "", "owner": 1, "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-01-21T02:22:38.142Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Measuring Our Impact", "sub_title": "", "seo_title": "", "slug": "moi-landing-page", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "top_stories": [{"sector_name": "

Health

", "url": 32, "link_caption": "link to full Health page", "sort_order": 0, "top_stories_content": "

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods – and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they’re taking home – whether they’re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.", "pk": null, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Our Community

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.", "pk": null, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 25, "link_caption": "link to full Education page", "sort_order": 2, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX%  of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": null, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

", "pk": null, "page": 42}], "main_content": "

Farm to school is changing/transforming Oregon for the better…

There is a growing network of schools committed to putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations. Through their work, kids, families, and communities are reaping the benefits:


", "numchild": 1, "content_type": 2, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "00010003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 2, "first_published_at": "2015-12-28T23:17:35.597Z", "expire_at": null}

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! ", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. ", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX%  of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX%  of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

", "numbers": "14, 81, 1700"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-01-24T02:58:15.671Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Measuring Our Impact", "seo_title": "", "slug": "moi-landing-page", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "top_stories": [{"sector_name": "

Health

", "url": 32, "link_caption": "link to full Health page", "sort_order": 0, "top_stories_content": "

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods – and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they’re taking home – whether they’re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.

", "pk": 1, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Our Community

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 25, "link_caption": "link to full Education page", "sort_order": 2, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX%  of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

", "pk": 4, "page": 42}], "numchild": 1, "content_type": 2, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "00010003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 2, "first_published_at": "2015-12-28T23:17:35.597Z", "expire_at": null}

Health

", "url": 32, "link_caption": "link to full Health page", "sort_order": 0, "top_stories_content": "

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods – and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they’re taking home – whether they’re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.

", "pk": 1, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Our Community

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 25, "link_caption": "link to full Education page", "sort_order": 2, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX%  of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

", "pk": 4, "page": 42}], "numchild": 1, "content_type": 2, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "00010003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 2, "first_published_at": "2015-12-28T23:17:35.597Z", "expire_at": null}

{"display_title": "

Oregon

Farm to School Counts

", "search_description": "", "owner": 1, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"number_count_up\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

In 2016, Farm to school is transforming Oregon, generating $21 million & 100 jobs for our communities and feeding 567000 kids.

\", \"inline\": false, \"numbers\": \"21; 100; 567000\"}}, {\"type\": \"paragraph\", \"value\": \"

Farm to school is changing/transforming Oregon for the better...

There is a growing network of schools committed to putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations. Through their work, kids, families, and communities are reaping the benefits:\\u00a0

\"}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-01-27T22:31:49.390Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Measuring Our Impact", "seo_title": "", "slug": "moi-landing-page", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "top_stories": [{"sector_name": "

Health

", "url": 48, "link_caption": "Link to Health page", "sort_order": 0, "top_stories_content": "

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods \u2013 and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state\u2019s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they\u2019re taking home \u2013 whether they\u2019re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.


", "pk": null, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 47, "link_caption": "link to Education page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom


Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools \u2013 an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees \u2013 cooks, teachers, and administrators \u2013 need support for ongoing education and training of their own.


", "pk": null, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Economy

", "url": 46, "link_caption": "link to Economy page", "sort_order": 2, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school


When it comes to Oregon\u2019s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.


", "pk": null, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.\u00a0

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens \u2013 that\u2019s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We\u2019re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste?\u00a0


", "pk": null, "page": 42}], "numchild": 5, "content_type": 2, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "00010003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 2, "first_published_at": "2015-12-28T23:17:35.597Z", "expire_at": null}

There is a growing network of schools committed to putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations. Through their work, kids, families, and communities are reaping the benefits:\u00a0

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods – and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 47, "link_caption": "link to Education page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom


Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": 7, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. 

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We’re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? 


", "pk": 8, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.


", "pk": 6, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Economy

", "url": 46, "link_caption": "link to Economy page", "sort_order": 2, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.


", "pk": 7, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

", "url": 25, "link_caption": "link to full Education page", "sort_order": 2, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom

Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX%  of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. 

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We’re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? 


", "pk": 8, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods – and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they’re taking home – whether they’re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. 

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We’re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? 


", "pk": 8, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

", "url": 47, "link_caption": "link to Education page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom


Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "url": 32, "link_caption": "link to full Health page", "sort_order": 0, "top_stories_content": "

Building healthy kids & communities

Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods – and schools have been stepping up to the challenge:

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they’re taking home – whether they’re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.

", "pk": 5, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Our Community

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 47, "link_caption": "link to Education page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom


Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.


", "pk": 6, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. 

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We’re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? 


", "pk": 8, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year).

We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they’re taking home – whether they’re sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.

", "url": 4, "link_caption": "link to full Community page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Growing a new economy with farm to school

When it comes to Oregon’s economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budgets on local food. Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 47, "link_caption": "link to Education page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom


Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. 

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We’re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? 


", "pk": 8, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 35, "link_caption": "link to environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

Recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon infused $4.5 million in Farm to School and School Garden programs in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.

There is so much more we can do to support the relationships that make these transactions possible, from providing opportunities for schools and farmers to connect, to promoting the good work they are already doing for their communities. And more we can do to make these economic benefits available to everyone, looking across the supply chain at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

", "pk": 2, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Education

", "url": 47, "link_caption": "link to Education page", "sort_order": 1, "top_stories_content": "

Local food by the books: Learning in the cafeteria and classroom


Early farm to school adopters blazed a trail for teaching kids about food, and for using food as a gateway to learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. To smooth the path for their peers, the state launched Oregon Harvest for Schools – an educational toolkit to help teach kids about local food. The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program also provides grants for educational programming, and currently reaches XXX children, or XX% of students in the state. However, we know every school could benefit from having access to this critical education.

To keep the momentum going, we need to know more about the impact of Farm to School programs on food literacy for kids (and their families!), whether or not lessons about local food are keeping students engaged in the classroom, and how to align educational resources with state standards. If we want to see these programs flourish into the future, school employees – cooks, teachers, and administrators – need support for ongoing education and training of their own.

", "pk": 3, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Environment

", "url": 49, "link_caption": "link to Environment page", "sort_order": 3, "top_stories_content": "

Schools dig nature.


From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. 

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

We’re proud of our gardens and we want to know more. We could benefit from collecting more data on the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? 


", "pk": 8, "page": 42}, {"sector_name": "

Schools dig nature.

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens – that’s about 50% of all schools in the state! Gardens are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from carbon sequestration in soil, to its role in water quality and other ecosystem services. In fact, at least 244 of these school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

 We currently don’t do enough tracking, measuring, and evaluating of the environmental impacts of farm to school programs. Gardens are a great place to start, but how much carbon are they taking in? How much water does a cafeteria save by practicing meatless Mondays? Does a localized lunch reduce waste? There is so much to learn.

 In general, we have the least amount of data on environmental indicators. I’d like to end with something more general in this sector. Something along the lines of, we don’t do enough tracking/measurement/evaluation of the environmental impacts of our programs! School gardens are a great starting point, but what about environmentally sustainable foods, reducing cafeteria waste, etc?

{"locked": false, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Oregon Farm to School Counts is a project of the Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network.



The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network (OFSSGN) \\u00a0is a group of more than XX stakeholders across the state who are making these changes happen every day. This website is where we track our progress and measure our success at putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations.\\u00a0


Evaluation is needed for transformation

Oregon's farm to school movement cannot set goals or measure progress without data to show us where we're at. In 2013 the OFSSGN set to work identifying priorities and available data at a statewide level to measure the impact of our work. We were fortunate that a framework for evaluating the impact of farm to school, informed by multiple stakeholders and vetted by experts, was soon to be published by the National Farm to School Network (view the full framework here). We used this framework to inform our own efforts to measure and categorize our success. We were also fortunate that the USDA Farm to School census had started to provide data for many aspects of farm to school in Oregon, along with data collected via Oregon's farm to school grants.\\u00a0

\"}}]", "title": "About", "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": true, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 3, "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-03-22T02:45:26.225Z", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "content_type": 18, "path": "000100030002", "owner": 1, "pk": 45, "first_published_at": "2016-01-27T22:43:27.165Z", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/about/", "expired": false, "slug": "about", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

{"locked": false, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Oregon Farm to School Counts is a project of the Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network.



The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network (OFSSGN) \\u00a0is a group of more than XX stakeholders across the state who are making these changes happen every day. This website is where we track our progress and measure our success at putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations.\\u00a0


Evaluation is needed for transformation

Oregon's farm to school movement cannot set goals or measure progress without data to show us where we're at. In 2013 the OFSSGN set to work identifying priorities and available data at a statewide level to measure the impact of our work. We were fortunate that a framework for evaluating the impact of farm to school, informed by multiple stakeholders and vetted by experts, was soon to be published by the National Farm to School Network (view the full framework here). We used this framework to inform our own efforts to measure and categorize our success. We were also fortunate that the USDA Farm to School census had started to provide data for many aspects of farm to school in Oregon, along with data collected via Oregon's farm to school grants.\\u00a0

\"}}, {\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Evaluation Framework


Following NFSN's Evaluation for Transformation framework, Oregon's data is categorized into four broad sectors with the potential to influence outcomes for farm to school: Community Economic Development, Education, Public Health, and Environmental Quality [hot link to each sector, where a brief description of that sector can be found along with data]. For each of these Sectors, there are identified Priority Outcomes, short- and long-term changes or benefits that result from farm to school activities. Each outcome has an associated set of Indicators that reflect how a system is working and can help to understand causes of problems as well as ways to address them. Each Indicator has a set of Measures that help show how an indicator changes over time. Measures are the part of our evaluation framework where we collect, analyze, and display data that support the Indicators and Priority Outcomes in each Sector.

{"display_title": "
Education
", "search_description": "", "owner": 1, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Local food by the books - learning in the cafeteria & classroom

Farm to school seeks to support educational outcomes for students by promoting activities that engage children and families in learning about, and developing skills related to eating healthfully and understanding the food system. \\u00a0Farm to school curriculum and experiential activities are also a platform to teach core content areas such as science, math and language arts. \\u00a0Success in this sector is measured via student readiness to learn, engagement, and academic competency, student and adult food literacy, resource allocated to farm to school activities and training, and alignment of activities with state standards.

\"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-01-30T21:49:59.229Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Education", "seo_title": "", "slug": "education", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "numchild": 2, "content_type": 6, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "000100030004", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/education/", "expired": false, "pk": 47, "locked": false, "depth": 3, "first_published_at": "2016-01-30T21:49:59.240Z", "expire_at": null}

{"display_title": "
Economy
", "search_description": "", "owner": 1, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Growing a new economy with farm to school

Farm to school provides economic development opportunities to producers (e.g., farmers, ranchers, fishers), laborers, distributors, processors, cooks and foodservice staff, as well as others who support the local food system. \\u00a0Farm to school activities can help build long-term economic vitality within a local food system by creating demand for local food products. \\u00a0Success in this sector is measured via local and regional economic impact, market opportunities, income generation, and sociual capital.

\"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-01-30T21:47:14.125Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Community Economic Development", "seo_title": "", "slug": "community-economic-development", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "numchild": 3, "content_type": 6, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "000100030003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/community-economic-development/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 3, "first_published_at": "2016-01-30T21:47:14.137Z", "expire_at": null}

{"display_title": "
Environment
", "search_description": "", "owner": 1, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Schools dig nature

Farm to school activities can support practices that build healthy soil, clean air, clean water and ecosystem processes in urban, suburban and rural environments, while impacting participants' ecological ethics. \\u00a0Farm to school activities may also support environmentally sound, sustainable and just approaches to food production, processing, packaging, transportation and marketing. \\u00a0Success in this sector is measured via student and adult environmental literacy, environmentally friendly practices in schools, and support for sustainable food production methods and practices.

\"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-01-30T21:50:43.752Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Environmental Quality", "seo_title": "", "slug": "environmental-quality", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "numchild": 1, "content_type": 6, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "000100030006", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/environmental-quality/", "expired": false, "pk": 49, "locked": false, "depth": 3, "first_published_at": "2016-01-30T21:50:43.763Z", "expire_at": null}

Farm to school activities can support practices that build healthy soil, clean air, clean water and ecosystem processes in urban, suburban and rural environments, while impacting participants' ecological ethics. \\u00a0Farm to school activities may also support environmentally sound, sustainable and just approaches to food production, processing, packaging, transportation and marketing. \\u00a0Success in this sector is measured via student and adult environmental literacy, environmentally friendly practices in schools, and support for sustainable food production methods and practices.

", "search_description": "", "owner": 1, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Growing a new economy with farm to school

Farm to school provides economic development opportunities to producers (e.g., farmers, ranchers, fishers), laborers, distributors, processors, cooks and foodservice staff, as well as others who support the local food system. \\u00a0Farm to school activities can help build long-term economic vitality within a local food system by creating demand for local food products. \\u00a0Success in this sector is measured via local and regional economic impact, market opportunities, income generation, and sociual capital.

\"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-03-25T16:56:54.482Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Community Economic Development", "seo_title": "", "slug": "economy", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "numchild": 3, "content_type": 6, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "000100030003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/community-economic-development/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 3, "first_published_at": "2016-01-30T21:47:14.137Z", "expire_at": null}

{"locked": false, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Oregon Farm to School Counts is a project of the Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network.



The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network (OFSSGN) \\u00a0is a group of more than XX stakeholders across the state who are making these changes happen every day. This website is where we track our progress and measure our success at putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations.\\u00a0


Evaluation is needed for transformation

Oregon's farm to school movement cannot set goals or measure progress without data to show us where we're at. In 2013 the OFSSGN set to work identifying priorities and available data at a statewide level to measure the impact of our work. We were fortunate that a framework for evaluating the impact of farm to school, informed by multiple stakeholders and vetted by experts, was soon to be published by the National Farm to School Network (view the full framework here). We used this framework to inform our own efforts to measure and categorize our success. We were also fortunate that the USDA Farm to School census had started to provide data for many aspects of farm to school in Oregon, along with data collected via Oregon's farm to school grants.\\u00a0

\"}}, {\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Evaluation Framework


Following NFSN's Evaluation for Transformation framework, Oregon's data is categorized into four broad sectors with the potential to influence outcomes for farm to school: Community Economic Development, Education, Public Health, and Environmental Quality [hot link to each sector, where a brief description of that sector can be found along with data]. For each of these Sectors, there are identified Priority Outcomes, short- and long-term changes or benefits that result from farm to school activities. Each outcome has an associated set of Indicators that reflect how a system is working and can help to understand causes of problems as well as ways to address them. Each Indicator has a set of Measures that help show how an indicator changes over time. Measures are the part of our evaluation framework where we collect, analyze, and display data that support the Indicators and Priority Outcomes in each Sector.

\"}}]", "title": "About", "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": true, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 3, "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-03-22T03:45:03.125Z", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "content_type": 18, "path": "000100030002", "owner": 1, "pk": 45, "first_published_at": "2016-01-27T22:43:27.165Z", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/about/", "expired": false, "slug": "about", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

There is growing network of schools committed to putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations. Through their work, kids, families, and communities are reaping the benefits. We are proud to share our impact in four main areas.

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"health\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch.


Increasingly, schools are a critical point for students to access healthy foods - and schools have been stepping up to the challenge. Luckily, 130 school districts serving 89% of school meals in the state are providing healthy, local food through the state's Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program (2015-2016 School Year). We know that kids are eating better thanks to farm to school, but there is still a lot to learn about the lessons they're taking home - whether they're sharing new foods with their family or requesting healthy options at the grocery store.



\", \"colored_text\": \"53%\", \"numbers\": \"53\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all 15 Public Health measurements\", \"source\": \"

This is a source attribution\\u00a0Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aenean commodo ligula eget dolor. Aenean massa. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"education\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

Oregon Farm to School grants for food literacy reach XX,XXX students.

In 2015, over 800 teachers, parents, food service staff, and other community partners received trainings around the state, to be able to run farm to school programs in their own communities. \\u00a0These farm to school trailblazers are not only teaching kids about food, but are also using food as a gateway into learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. \\u00a0We also know that educational opportunities increase the chance that kids are going to try and like new fruits and vegetables, since it usually takes X-XX exposures to a new food before a child is ready to like it.

\", \"colored_text\": \"XX,XXX\", \"numbers\": \"\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all 9 Education Measurements\", \"source\": \"

source source source

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"economy\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

Farm to school is no small potatoes - Oregon invested $4.5 million in 2015, and is reaping the rewards.


When it comes to Oregon's economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budget on local food. \\u00a0Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. But, there's more work to be done, including working intentionally to make these economic benefits available to everyone across the supply chain, looking especially at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.

\", \"colored_text\": \"$4.5 million\", \"numbers\": \"\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all 12 Economic Measurements\", \"source\": \"

source source source

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"environment\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

605 Oregon schools have edible gardens - that's over 50% of all schools in the state!

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purcahsing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. \\u00a0Gardens and cafeterias are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from water quality and ecosystem services to composting and reducing food waste. \\u00a0In fact, at least 244 of Oregon's school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.

\", \"colored_text\": \"605; 50%\", \"numbers\": \"605\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all Environment Measurements\", \"source\": \"

environment source

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"education\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

Despite everything we know, we're still lacking adequate data for over 45 measures.

Some of the most important aspects of our work are also the most difficult to measure, from farm to school's impact on parents and families, to the percentage of sales that are benefitting socially-disadvantage producers, there's a lot that we could learn from continued research and evaluation.


\", \"colored_text\": \"45\", \"numbers\": \"45\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View the Data Gaps\", \"source\": \"

data gaps source

\"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-03-26T02:58:58.815Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Farm to School Counts", "seo_title": "", "slug": "moi-landing-page", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "top_stories": [], "numchild": 5, "content_type": 2, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "00010003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 2, "first_published_at": "2015-12-28T23:17:35.597Z", "expire_at": null}
