\\n\\n\"}}, {\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Oregon's evaluation framework


\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nIn line with the National Farm to School\\nNetwork\\u2019s evaluation framework, Oregon's data is categorized into four broad\\nsectors with the potential to influence outcomes for farm to school:\\u00a0Community Economic Development,\\u00a0Education,\\u00a0Public Health, and\\u00a0Environmental Quality.\\u00a0For each of these Sectors, there are identified Priority\\nOutcomes, which are the short- and long-term changes or benefits that\\nresult from farm to school activities. Each of these outcome has an associated\\nset of Indicators that reflect how a\\nsystem is working and can help us understand causes of problems as well as ways\\nto address them. Each Indicator has a set of Measures that help show how an indicator changes over time.\\nMeasures are the part of our evaluation framework where we collect, analyze,\\nand display data that support the Indicators and Priority Outcomes in each\\nSector. To download a word document of this website's entire framework, click here. This website displays measures for which we have accurate and reliable\\ndata at a statewide level. We also have a list of over 35 measures for which we\\nstill lack adequate statewide data. View those Wish List Measures here. \\u00a0This project\\nhas been funded at least in part with Federal funds from the U.S. Department of\\nAgriculture. The contents of this publication do not necessarily reflect the\\nview or policies of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, nor does mention of\\ntrade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the\\nU.S. Government.

\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\"}}]", "title": "About", "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": true, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 3, "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-05-04T21:37:39.493Z", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "content_type": 18, "path": "000100030002", "owner": 1, "pk": 45, "first_published_at": "2016-01-27T22:43:27.165Z", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/about/", "expired": false, "slug": "about", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "owner": 1, "body_content": "[{\"type\": \"number_count_up\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Farm to school is transforming Oregon - generating $21 million for our communities, 100+ jobs, and feeding 567000 kids.


\", \"colored_text\": \"$21; 100+; 567000\", \"numbers\": \"100; 567000; 21\", \"inline\": false}}, {\"type\": \"basic_content\", \"value\": {\"content\": \"

Welcome!


\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n

There is a growing network of\\nschools committed to putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers,\\nteaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy\\nfoods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future\\ngenerations. Because of their work, kids, families, and communities are reaping\\nthe benefits. We are proud to share our impact in four key areas:

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"health\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch.


\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n

That means that often, school\\nlunch is the most reliable source of food that Oregon kids have. It\\u2019s a\\ncritical meal, and deserves to be as good as we can possibly make it. Luckily, schools are stepping up to the challenge. In the 2015-2016 school year, 130\\nschool districts, serving 89% of Oregon school meals, were including healthy,\\nlocal food in those meals as a part of Oregon\\u2019s Farm to School and School\\nGarden Grant Program.

\", \"colored_text\": \"53%\", \"numbers\": \"53\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all 15 Public Health measurements\", \"source\": \"

Oregon Department of Education

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"education\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

Oregon Farm to School grants for food literacy reach 32000 students.

\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\u00a0In 2014, over 800 teachers, parents, food service staff, and other\\ncommunity partners received trainings around the state, to run farm to school\\nprograms in their own communities. In 2016, 24 school districts and community\\npartners received state grant funds to run educational programs. These farm to\\nschool trailblazers are not only teaching kids about food, but are also using\\nfood as a gateway into learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art\\nliteracy. These educational opportunities have the added benefit of increasing\\nthe likelihood that kids are going to try and like new fruits and vegetables,\\nsince it usually takes 10-15 exposures to a new food before a child is ready to\\nlike it.\\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0


\", \"colored_text\": \"32000\", \"numbers\": \"32000\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all 9 Education Measurements\", \"source\": \"

source source source

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"economy\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

In 2015, recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon decided to invest $4.5 million, and is reaping the rewards.


When it comes to Oregon's economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budget on local food. \\u00a0Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. But, there's more work to be done, including working intentionally to make these economic benefits available to everyone across the supply chain, looking especially at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.


\", \"colored_text\": \"2015; $4.5 million\", \"numbers\": \"\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all 12 Economic Measurements\", \"source\": \"

source source source

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"environment\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

618 schools have edible gardens-- that's over 50% of all schools in the state!

\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nFrom growing school gardens, to sustainable food\\npurchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice.\\nGardens and cafeterias are essential classrooms where students can learn about\\neverything from water quality and ecosystem services to composting and reducing\\nfood waste. In fact, at least 244 of Oregon\\u2019s school gardens are used to\\nsupport curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics\\nof students.\\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0


\", \"colored_text\": \"618; 50%\", \"numbers\": \"618\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View all Environment Measurements\", \"source\": \"

environment source

\"}}, {\"type\": \"top_story\", \"value\": {\"sector\": \"data-gaps\", \"content\": {\"content\": \"

Despite everything we know, there are still plenty of gaps in Oregon's farm to school data. Of more than 60 measures identified as priorities for measurement at statewide level, we lack adequate data for more than half of them.

\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nSome of the most important aspects of our work\\nare also the most difficult to measure, from farm to school\\u2019s impact on parents\\nand families, to the percentage of sales that are benefitting\\nsocially-disadvantaged producers, there\\u2019s a lot that we could learn from\\ncontinued research and evaluation.\\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0


\", \"colored_text\": \"60\", \"numbers\": \"60\", \"inline\": false}, \"link_caption\": \"View the Data Gaps\", \"source\": \"

data gaps source

\"}}]", "latest_revision_created_at": "2016-05-04T16:48:16.778Z", "go_live_at": null, "title": "Farm to School Counts", "seo_title": "", "slug": "moi-landing-page", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "top_stories": [], "numchild": 5, "content_type": 2, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "00010003", "url_path": "/moi-landing-page/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 2, "first_published_at": "2015-12-28T23:17:35.597Z", "expire_at": null}

fields.body_content:
[{"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Oregon Farm to School Counts is a project of the Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network.


The Oregon Farm to School and School Garden Network (OFSSGN) is a group of more than 900 stakeholders across the state who are making these changes happen every day. This website is where we track our progress and measure our success at putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations.


Evaluation is needed for transformation

Oregon's farm to school movement cannot set goals or measure progress without data to show us where we're at. In 2013 the OFSSGN set to work identifying priorities and available data at a statewide level to measure the impact of our work. We were fortunate that a framework for evaluating the impact of farm to school, informed by multiple stakeholders and vetted by experts, was soon to be published by the National Farm to School Network  (view the full framework here). We used this framework to inform our own efforts to measure and categorize our success. We were also fortunate that the USDA Farm to School Census had started to provide data for many aspects of farm to school in Oregon, and Oregon partners had begun collecting data via Oregon's farm to school and school garden grant program.


Oregon's farm to school data.

The USDA Farm to School Census provides one source of data for topics such as how districts define local, the amount of dollars invested in local foods, and types of local foods purchased, for many Oregon school districts. First launched in the 2011-12 school year and repeated every two years, the census provides a reliable snapshot of many aspects of farm to school in Oregon. The state of Oregon also collects data from all recipients of its farm to school and school garden grant program. The data collected on these districts is fairly comprehensive and includes total dollars spent on local products, number of educational activities conducted, and more. Data available from other sources helps to fill in holes in the census and state grant data. For example, the Oregon Department of Education tracks the number of school gardens at every single school in the state.

"}}, {"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Oregon's evaluation framework


In line with the National Farm to School Network’s evaluation framework, Oregon's data is categorized into four broad sectors with the potential to influence outcomes for farm to school: Community Economic Development, Education, Public Health, and Environmental Quality. For each of these Sectors, there are identified Priority Outcomes, which are the short- and long-term changes or benefits that result from farm to school activities. Each of these outcome has an associated set of Indicators that reflect how a system is working and can help us understand causes of problems as well as ways to address them. Each Indicator has a set of Measures that help show how an indicator changes over time. Measures are the part of our evaluation framework where we collect, analyze, and display data that support the Indicators and Priority Outcomes in each Sector. To download a word document of this website's entire framework, click here. This website displays measures for which we have accurate and reliable data at a statewide level. We also have a list of over 35 measures for which we still lack adequate statewide data. View those Wish List Measures here.  This project has been funded at least in part with Federal funds from the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The contents of this publication do not necessarily reflect the view or policies of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, nor does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.

"}}]

fields.body_content:
[{"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Calculate the impact of your school's local spending


Farm to school provides economic development opportunities to producers (e.g., farmers, ranchers, fishers), laborers, distributors, processors, cooks and foodservice staff, as well as others who support the local food system. Farm to school activities can help build long-term economic vitality by creating demand for local food products. Success in this sector is measured via local and regional economic impact, market opportunities, income generation, and social capital.

"}}]

fields.display_title: Education
fields.body_content:
[{"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Local food by the books - learning in the cafeteria & classroom

Farm to school seeks to support educational outcomes for students by promoting activities that engage children and families in learning about, and developing skills related to eating healthfully and understanding the food system. Farm to school curricula and experiential activities are also a platform to teach core content areas such as science, math, and language arts. Success in this sector is measured via student readiness to learn, engagement, and academic competency, student and adult food literacy, resources allocated to farm to school activities and training, and alignment of activities with state standards.



"}}]

fields.display_title: Health
fields.body_content:
[{"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Building healthy kids and communities

Farm to school activities aim to provide healthy local food options and nutrition and food-based education to influence healthy eating behaviors and healthy lifestyles in children and their families. Success in this sector is measured by looking at student and family access to, awareness of, preferences for, and consumption of locally produced healthy food in schools and communities.



"}}]

fields.display_title: Environment
fields.body_content:
[{"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Schools dig nature

Farm to school activities can support practices that build healthy soil, clean air, and clean water in urban, suburban and rural environments, while impacting participants' ecological ethics. Farm to school activities may also support environmentally sound, sustainable, and just approaches to food production, processing, packaging, transportation, and marketing. Success in this sector is measured via student and adult environmental literacy, environmentally friendly practices in schools, and support for sustainable food production methods and practices.



"}}]

fields.display_title: Data Gaps
fields.body_content:
[{"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Areas for further research


The farm to school movement is still relatively young, and there are many potential benefits that have not yet been thoroughly researched or understood. Some of the most important aspects of this work are also the most difficult to measure. In Oregon and across the country, these are some of the key areas where additional studies are needed.\u00a0What follows is a high-level summary of areas that would benefit from additional statewide research and data collection. To download the entire list of measures and data gaps identified by the Oregon Farm to School and School Garden network, click here.


Public Health

  1. The number of school districts that use of local, healthy foods in school meal programs beyond lunch (e.g.\u00a0breakfast,\u00a0snacks, summer,\u00a0and\u00a0afterschool\u00a0programs).
  2. Percentage of districts with farm to school programs that are in full\u00a0compliance\u00a0with federal school meal regulations.
  3. Number and type of nutrition, food-based or agriculture-based learning\u00a0materials sent home\u00a0or shared with other community adults.
  4. Number of\u00a0parents or care-givers\u00a0participating in farm to school activities, such as after-school programs, garden volunteers, field trips, nutrition and food-based learning, etc.
  5. The number of\u00a0training and support opportunities for students and their families to grow and prepare their own food.
  6. Number of\u00a0families that begin gardening\u00a0at home or in a community garden after participation in farm to school activities.
  7. Number of\u00a0families who report purchasing local foods\u00a0after involvement in farm to school activities.
  8. Number or percentage of local school district\u00a0wellness policies\u00a0that include language on farm to school activities as part of addressing nutrition and wellness efforts.
  9. Number or percentage of schools with Farm to School programs (including procurement, promotion and/or education) reporting\u00a0school specific\u00a0written wellness policies\u00a0in addition to the district policy, that include Farm to School programming.
  10. Increase in\u00a0student and family awareness and knowledge\u00a0about food and nutrition\u2019s impact on health.
  11. Increase in\u00a0student and family willingness\u00a0to try new local, healthy foods.
  12. Amount\u00a0of local fruits and vegetables students and families report eating.


Education

  1. Number of participating in farm to school and school garden activities aligned to Early Learning Framework, Common Core or state-adopted content standards.
  2. The subjects (i.e., nutrition, science), grade levels, frequency and number of classes, and type of activities (i.e., taste tests, hands-on learning, gardening) where farm to school activities and curriculum are aligned to Early Learning Framework, Common Core or state-adopted content standards.
  3. Number or percentage of school gardens that have a designated, funded School Garden staff position (School Garden Coordinator or Educator).\u00a0
  4. Number of school districts that are using Oregon Harvest for Schools materials.
  5. Number of students who are receiving educational activities that are able to demonstrate knowledge of where their food comes from and how it is grown.
  6. Knowledge of at least one element of food heritage, such as foods unique to different cultures, and including food histories native to the region/community/their own family\u00a0
  7. Number or percentage of students participating in, or exposed to, farm to school educational activities, such as school gardening, farm field trips, Future Farmers of America, cooking, nutrition and food-based lessons.


Community Economic Development\u00a0

  1. Number or percentage of school districts that have increased the variety of local and Oregon products they serve. \u00a0
  2. Number or percentage of school districts that have increased the frequency at which they serve local and Oregon products.\u00a0
  3. Amount, in pounds, of Oregon-grown or locally-grown or raised products purchased by Oregon school districts.
  4. Farm access to a distribution network to distribute their products to Oregon\u2019s schools.
  5. Percentage of school food sales that go to local socially disadvantaged producers (i.e., growers, ranchers, processors).
  6. Number and type of food-related businesses (i.e., farmers, ranchers, distributors, retailers) partnering with the school district to support farm to school through education, gardening and procurement efforts (i.e., field trips, site visits).
  7. Existence of collaborative research into local farm to school and school garden programs and policies in Oregon (may include local non-profits, schools, districts, the Oregon Health Authority, ODE and ODA, OSU Extension, and others within and outside the state).
  8. Existing programs, such as Oregon State Extension Master Gardeners, Oregon State University Extension 4-H School Garden Program, FFA, Oregon Health Authority, Oregon Food Bank and public state universities (i.e. OSU, Eastern Oregon University, U of O, PSU) collaborate with other farm to school and school garden stakeholders across the state to efficiently utilize existing resources to support farm to school and school garden efforts.\u00a0
  9. Number or percentage of state and local procurement policies with language encouraging purchases of locally grown and processed foods. \u00a0
  10. State agency funding includes funding for school districts to link cafeteria with classroom/garden activities.
  11. State agency funding is provided to school districts to engage the community in their farm to school efforts.
  12. Funding for implementation of state farm to school grants includes funding for districts, ODE or other entities to track and monitor local purchases.
  13. Number of training opportunities created for local producers and businesses owned by socially disadvantaged individuals, to help them work with schools.


Environmental Quality

  1. Number of students receiving educational activities who are able to demonstrate knowledge, skills and motivation to make responsible food choices and an understanding of how these choices impact their health, the environment and their community.
  2. Number of children, grade levels, and length of time spent visiting local farmers to learn about sustainable food production methods.
  3. Quantity purchased and amount spent on local foods that are also third-party eco-label certified foods.
  4. Quantity purchased and amount spent on local foods that are grown on farms with diversified crops.
  5. Number of school-based composting programs that are part of existing waste reduction programs or are stand-alone.


"}}]

[{"type": "number_count_up", "value": {"content": "

Farm to school is transforming Oregon - generating $21 million for our communities, 100+ jobs, and feeding 567000 kids.


", "colored_text": "$21; 100+; 567000", "numbers": "100; 567000; 21", "inline": false}}, {"type": "basic_content", "value": {"content": "

Welcome!


There is a growing network of schools committed to putting more money in the pockets of Oregon's farmers, teaching students about farm fresh foods, increasing access to local healthy foods in schools and preschools, and stewarding the land for future generations. Because of their work, kids, families, and communities are reaping the benefits. We are proud to share our impact in four key areas:

"}}, {"type": "top_story", "value": {"sector": "health", "content": {"content": "

In Oregon, 53% of kids qualify for free and reduced lunch.


That means that often, school lunch is the most reliable source of food that Oregon kids have. It’s a critical meal, and deserves to be as good as we can possibly make it. Luckily, schools are stepping up to the challenge. In the 2015-2016 school year, 130 school districts, serving 89% of Oregon school meals, were including healthy, local food in those meals as a part of Oregon’s Farm to School and School Garden Grant Program.

", "colored_text": "53%", "numbers": "53", "inline": false}, "link_caption": "View all 15 Public Health measurements", "source": "

Oregon Department of Education

"}}, {"type": "top_story", "value": {"sector": "education", "content": {"content": "

Oregon Farm to School grants for food literacy reach 32000 students.

 In 2014, over 800 teachers, parents, food service staff, and other community partners received trainings around the state, to run farm to school programs in their own communities. In 2016, 24 school districts and community partners received state grant funds to run educational programs. These farm to school trailblazers are not only teaching kids about food, but are also using food as a gateway into learning about all sorts of subjects, from math to art literacy. These educational opportunities have the added benefit of increasing the likelihood that kids are going to try and like new fruits and vegetables, since it usually takes 10-15 exposures to a new food before a child is ready to like it.    


", "colored_text": "32000", "numbers": "32000", "inline": false}, "link_caption": "View all 9 Education Measurements", "source": "

Oregon Department of Education; Oregon State Lead for the National Farm to School Network

"}}, {"type": "top_story", "value": {"sector": "economy", "content": {"content": "

In 2015, recognizing that farm to school is no small potatoes, Oregon decided to invest $4.5 million, and is reaping the rewards.


When it comes to Oregon's economy, the impact of school food is on the rise: Oregon schools spend about a quarter of their budget on local food.  Farm to school generated more than $21 million and 100 jobs in the 2011-2012 school year. But, there's more work to be done, including working intentionally to make these economic benefits available to everyone across the supply chain, looking especially at opportunities to support socially disadvantaged producers, farmworkers, and laborers.


", "colored_text": "2015; $4.5 million", "numbers": "", "inline": false}, "link_caption": "View all 12 Economic Measurements", "source": "

source source source

"}}, {"type": "top_story", "value": {"sector": "environment", "content": {"content": "

618 schools have edible gardens-- that's over 50% of all schools in the state!

From growing school gardens, to sustainable food purchasing and composting, farm to school is an earth friendly practice. Gardens and cafeterias are essential classrooms where students can learn about everything from water quality and ecosystem services to composting and reducing food waste. In fact, at least 244 of Oregon’s school gardens are used to support curriculum, strengthening environmental literacy and ecological ethics of students.    


", "colored_text": "618; 50%", "numbers": "618", "inline": false}, "link_caption": "View all Environment Measurements", "source": "

Oregon Department of Education school garden survey

"}}, {"type": "top_story", "value": {"sector": "data-gaps", "content": {"content": "

Of the more than 60 measures identified as statewide priorities, we still lack adequate data for more than half of them.

Some of the most important aspects of our work are also the most difficult to measure, from farm to school’s impact on parents and families, to the percentage of sales that are benefitting socially-disadvantaged producers, there’s a lot that we could learn from continued research and evaluation.    


", "colored_text": "60", "numbers": "60", "inline": false}, "link_caption": "View the Data Gaps", "source": "

data gaps source

"}}]
